page.title: 09SELSFIELD COMMON I
page.content: This is one of the highest points in the area, about 190m, and was an old {beacon}site. The Common was enclosed in the 19th century but in{1912}seven acres were conveyed to the{National {Trust}by{Lord Arthur Hill}of the Old House, West Hoathly, and since 1914 it has been administered by{West Hoathly {Parish Council.}It is crossed by the course of an old{Roman Road}and also by a{smugglers' track.}Until early this century there was a{windmill}and the 18th century mill house and older tile-hung mill cottages are still there.{Old Selsfield}is a timber framed house of the 17th century with a barn of similar date. The common is lightly wooded with deciduous trees and there are patches of{bilberries. The{warden}is responsible "...for the provision of glades and for mowing the grass."
